Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Perception of place-of-articulation contrasts in English word-final consonants by Japanese adult L2 learners

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
People have difficulties communicating with non-native speakers, both understanding their speech and being understood. This study examines the difficulties that non-native English learners have in understanding continuous speech. English word-final consonants in connected speech are produced very differently from those produced in isolation; this phenomenon is referred to as coarticulation. The proposed study will examine the identification of words ending with /p/, /t/, /k/, /b/, /d/, /g/, /m/, /n/, and /ng/ (as in "king") followed by a word beginning with /p/, /t/ or /k/ in meaningful sentences by Japanese listeners. The task is to identify the target word in minimal triplets (e.g., sip, sit, sick) after listening to a sentence, such as "He said the word "sip" (or "sit" or "sick") positively" (or "tauntingly" or "cautiously"). The sentences will be spoken in both "clear speech" and in "fast conversational speech" styles. The former is used when native English speakers know that the listener may have difficulty understanding them; the latter is used when speaking with friends.

The proposed studies will investigate whether Japanese listeners have difficulty recognizing the final consonants in English words relative to native English listeners. whether their error patterns are different from those of English listeners, and whether they perform significantly better when the sentences are produced in "clear speech" style. Correctly identifying English word-final stops is expected to be challenging for Japanese listeners because Japanese words do not end in word-final consonants, with the exception of a nasal stop (/N/). Word-final nasal stops are also potentially confusable because the Japanese nasal is produced as /m/ /n/ or /ng/ depending on the following consonant. These data will have implications for how native speakers can modify their speech to improve communication with non-native speakers in English language classrooms and in work environments.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In running speech, the pronunciation of each word is constantly affected by that of its adjacent words, and individual words in a sentence may sound quite differently from those carefully produced in isolation. Cross-language studies have pointed out non-native listeners’ perceptual difficulties with English word-final consonants in isolated words but not in phrases or sentences, in spite of the fact that spoken words are usually produced in phrases and sentences in normal communicative situations.

The present study investigated the perception of English word-final consonants followed by a word-initial consonant in sentences. It specifically examined the perception of English words ending with /p/, /t/, /k/, /b/, /d/, /g/, /m/, /n/, and /?/ (as in king) followed by a word beginning with /p/, /t/, /k/ in a meaningful context by adult Japanese second language learners of English. Participants were asked to identify the target word, such as sip, out of a written set of similar-sounding word triplet, such as  sip, sit, and sick, after listening to a stimulus sentence, such as He said the word ____ positively, He said the word ____ tauntingly, and He said the word ____ cautiously.

In Japanese, words are structured in such a way that a consonant is almost always followed by a vowel, not allowing word-final consonants except for a nasal consonant called moraic nasal /N/. Thus, the consonants such as /p/, /t/, /k/, /b/, /d/, and /g/ (oral stops, hereafter) are always forced to be released because of the following vowel in Japanese. Furthermore, the Japanese word-final moraic nasal may be realized as either [m], [n], or [?], totally depending on the following consonant, making no distinction among the three consonants in word-final position. Thus, for Japanese listeners, correctly perceiving English word-final consonants followed by another consonant is expected to be challenging in two ways; if the word-final consonant is an oral stop, it will be difficult, especially when it is not released, because word-final oral stops do not exist in Japanese; if the word-final consonant is nasal, it will be difficult because of the unidentified nature of the word-final nasal consonant in Japanese. The present study was conducted using two different speech modes: clearly articulated speech (Clear Speech, hereafter); and casual fast speech (Fast Speech, hereafter).

Forty eight Japanese subjects (24 for Clear Speech experiment and 24 for Fast Speech experiment) and 36 American English subjects (12 for Clear Speech experiment and 24 for Fast Speech experiment) participated in the experiment. Results indicated that identifying English word-final oral stops in Fast speech, where the final stops were almost always unreleased, was very challenging for Japanese listeners (overall errors = 26 %). On the other hand, Japanese listeners’ perception in Clear Speech, where the final stops were very often released, was much better (6 % errors). The results also showed that Japanese listeners had serious difficulty in identifying word-final nasals in both conditions (23 % errors in Clear speech, 34% errors in Fast speech).

The present study shed light on perceptual problems that Japanese second language learners of English face when listening to English running speech. The findings of this study provided insight into the acoustic information that native-English-speaking listeners tap into for successful perception of word-final consonants in sentences, which may not be utilized effectively by non-native listeners of English.
